newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: "Millenium bug" may cost Irish firms 1.5 bln punts.
newsitem.headline: "Millenium bug" may cost Irish firms 1.5 bln punts.

text.p: Solving the "millenium bug" will cost Irish businesses around 1.5 billion Irish pounds between now and 1999, a British expert on the problem said on Tuesday.

Sean O'Reilly of the British Government Year 2000 Task Force told a Dublin seminar on the issue that the arrival of the millenium was the largest problem ever to face the information technology industry.

The so-called millenium bug results from the fact that computer systems use a two-digit format to show the year. At the turn of the century, many computers will interpret the year as 1900 rather than 2000, potentially creating havoc.
"The simplicity of the problem defies belief but the consequences of failing to resolve it are too serious to contemplate," O'Reilly said.

"Testing is going to be the most time consuming and expensive part of the solution, amounting to 55 percent of the cost for companies and requiring resources which are currently in heavy demand," he added.
O'Reilly said the cost of corrective work on computers would rise in the lead up to the deadline as resources became more difficult to find.

He said if a company began work in 1996 it would have cost between 0.70 to 1.06 Irish pounds per line of code, in 1997 this cost had increased to between 1.30 and 1.50 pounds and in 1998 it would again increase to between 2.00 and 2.50 pounds.
"If you start in 1999, forget it, you'll be too late," O'Reilly said.
